name: voluntary alert zone 50000
information:
Southern Resident Killer Whale Voluntary Alert Zone
Please be vigilant - a confirmed sighting occurred in this area within the previous 6 hours.

In U.S. Waters Stay at Least 100 yards away from all Whales & Orcas

In State Waters:
  • Stay at least 300 yards on either side.
  • Stay 400 yards away in front of and behind the whales.
  • Go slow (<7 knots) within 1/2 mile of Southern Resident killer whales.
  • Disengage engines if whales appear within 300 yards.


Recommended:
  • Stay at least 1000 yards from Southern Residents (will become law January 1, 2025
  • Turn off fish finders and echosounders when it is safe to do so.
  • Refrain from fishing, where possible within 1,000 yards, or a half mile, of whales.
  • If kayaking, raft up.


Regional Partners:
Acartia.io
Orca Network
Orcasound
The Whale Trail


Powered By:
Whale Alert
Acartia.io

name: voluntary alert zone 50002
information:
Humpback Whale Voluntary Alert Zone


In U.S. Waters Stay at Least 100 yards away from all Whales & Orcas

Recommended:
  • Look in all directions before planning your approach or departure.
  • BE CAUTIOUS and COURTEOUS: approach areas of known or suspected marine wildlife activity with extreme caution.
  • DO NOT APPROACH whales from the front or from behind. Always approach and depart whales from the side, moving in a direction parallel to the direction of the whales.
  • STAY on the OFFSHORE side of the whales when they are traveling close to shore.
  • LIMIT your viewing time to a recommended maximum of 30 minutes. This will minimize the cumulative impact of many vessels and give consideration to other viewers.
  • Slow down. Speed should not be more than 7 knots when 200 to 400m from a whale.
  • Do not position beside "bait balls" of small schooling fish (as indicated by aggregations of birds).
  • Do not approach within 200m. If a whale surfaces within 200m of your vessel, place engine in neutral (or ideally shut off the engine) until the whales are beyond 200m.
  • If kayaking, raft up.


Regional Partners:
Acartia.io
Orca Network
Orcasound
The Whale Trail


Powered By:
Whale Alert
Acartia.io

  • Stay at least 300 yards on either side.
  • Stay 400 yards away in front of and behind the whales.
  • Go slow (<7 knots) within 1/2 mile of Southern Resident killer whales.
  • Disengage engines if whales appear within 300 yards.


Recommended:
  • Stay at least 1000 yards from Southern Residents (will become law January 1, 2025
  • Turn off fish finders and echosounders when it is safe to do so.
  • Refrain from fishing, where possible within 1,000 yards, or a half mile, of whales.
  • If kayaking, raft up.


Regional Partners:
Acartia.io
Orca Network
Orcasound
The Whale Trail


Powered By:
Whale Alert
Acartia.io

name: voluntary alert zone 50037
information:
Humpback Whale Voluntary Alert Zone


In U.S. Waters Stay at Least 100 yards away from all Whales & Orcas

Recommended:
  • Look in all directions before planning your approach or departure.
  • BE CAUTIOUS and COURTEOUS: approach areas of known or suspected marine wildlife activity with extreme caution.
  • DO NOT APPROACH whales from the front or from behind. Always approach and depart whales from the side, moving in a direction parallel to the direction of the whales.
  • STAY on the OFFSHORE side of the whales when they are traveling close to shore.
  • LIMIT your viewing time to a recommended maximum of 30 minutes. This will minimize the cumulative impact of many vessels and give consideration to other viewers.
  • Slow down. Speed should not be more than 7 knots when 200 to 400m from a whale.
  • Do not position beside "bait balls" of small schooling fish (as indicated by aggregations of birds).
  • Do not approach within 200m. If a whale surfaces within 200m of your vessel, place engine in neutral (or ideally shut off the engine) until the whales are beyond 200m.
  • If kayaking, raft up.


Regional Partners:
